content: Fixed the typo in the statement as reported in the forum: https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-what-the-brainfuck/185745/34

As part of the discussion about tags, do you think we need to keep "brainfuck" as a tag? I've made "Interpreters" an official one.

https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/learning-tags-cleanup-normalization/186567/5

UPDATE:
The I (inputs count) input was renamed N to avoid stub generator problems in some languages.

IMPORTANT UPDATE:
After viewing the JBM's stream (Replay here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NrLvYwdV6ig), reading his post (Here: https://cg.desast.re/pages/2020-08-08-brainfuck.html), and talking with him and Zorg1, I decided to make a few changes on the puzzle.
First, the two kinds of input errors were more constraining than interesting, and were more about the puzzle format constraints than real interpreter problems. (At least concerning the missing input one.). So I removed them, and so the corresponding tests and validators.
Secondly, the 3 remaining errors validators are the exact inverses of their corresponding tests. To avoid incomplete solutions to pass, and also to check the correct management of the errors priority, I added the "Multiple errors" test/validator.
Despite this changes, the already validated solutions which totally fulfilled the puzzle requirements are still valids.
All this changes are also indicated in the statement.

You chose to have input come as decimal numbers instead of ASCII.

That's (debatably) fine, but it does raise a concern with regard to the input section: how do you specify what gets in there? The stub declares them as ints, but there's no hint of that in the statement, let alone a range constraint.

✅ Approved the contribution.
User declined to leave a comment.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's work on my machine with my programming language

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment:
Why is it still WIP?

Is there an order to output error message. I mean against SYNTAX ERROR.
This could output INCORRECT VALUE :
1 2 0
+[>-
As an interpreter errors are encountered along the way ?

It is of course your choice as the author, but I'm curious about the 2 things: (a) why you are not allowing integer overflow/wraparound (i.e. '-' on 0 making it 255 and vice verse), and (b) why do you want to use integers-printed-as-text for inputs rather than actually taking character bytes from the input and use their ASCII values making it closer to an actual BF interpreter?
For the error message, if some output occurs before the error detection, what must be displayed ? only the error message ?

A few typos:
that consist => that consists
allow you => allows you
come by pairs => come in pairs
all of this => all of these
OUT OF BOUND => OUT OF BOUNDS

It would be good to have a simpler testcase first, without loops.
What about:
1 1 0
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++.+.+.
to print
ABC
Looks like the stub is not reading S
first '[' correspond to the last ']' : it's false in fact if you have a program like that : ...[....]...[....]... (or perhaps I don't understand the sentence)
No you're right. I'll change that to "In case of nested [] the first [ always correspond to the last ]".
Yes, I Forgot to change it when added S...
Good idea. I'll add it.
Corrected !
The outputs must be displayed only if no error occurs. That's why I said "or" in the output description. It's not clear enough ?

The both are linked since the lowers ASCII characters are not printable. 
Either I allow integer 'wraparound' like you say, and I use the input characters ASCII values instead of integers, but with printable ASCII characters an operation like multiplication will automatically overflow.
Or I put integers as inputs and  so I can pass small values and the multiplication result stay under 255. And so I forbid the integer 'wraparound' to add a little 'difficulty'. ^^

The first error encountered must stop the execution and be printed. 
So in your example, when on the [ the interpreter must check the presence of a ] and so rise a SYNTAX ERROR. 
But it seems that's not clear enough in the statement. I will precise this.
Thanks !
EDIT: But to be logic, the SYNTAX ERROR must be raised before all the "runtime" ones. I will change the statement in this way.

You're in a hurry ? ^^
Just to let everyone who want the time to comment... But since the last comment is 6 days old, I think I will publish now. :)
Inputs section and statement corrected.
You don't need to mention that in the statement ("UPDATE 2") as it does not change anything about the approach/solution (it makes no difference for people having already solved the problem).
I don't know, perhaps it's a little specific...

Some people were confronted to this problem, and I done the change immediately, so I notified it as many places as possible. Especially that this change was done when the puzzle was "puzzle of the week".
But I agree, the "Update" section is no longer useful now...
Ok, I was only referring to the second update anyway (the first update was indeed interesting to mention for people having already solved / tried to solve the problem).

Oups i come back to late so Just in case !

Ok for SYNTAX ERROR first but then it would be nice to have some test cases with several errors to check priority -> my false version is ok with this set !

"[ jump to the instruction after the corresponding ]"... that mean in this example : [] -> output should be POINTER OUT OF BOUNDS ? I assume not because it's finally the end of the program...

I agree about a "multiple errors" test case, but I don't  know if it's a good idea to add it now that the puzzle is accepted...
About the [] instructions, the pointer role is to designate the current memory block and has nothing to do with the progression in the Brainfuck code. The end of the code is the end of the program.

I see. Well, another solution would be to either (a) adjust values after the input to make them smaller before performing operations or (b) have a short piece of BF to actually parse the input ASCII characters and construct the corresponding numbers (so that reading "42\n" would require reading 3 characters - two digits and a separator (space/end-of-line) character.
Effectively... But finally, the difference between the three possibilities is minim. So I will keep the current version. :)

don't see this sentence :( 
it' ok for me
Cool ! :)
